name: Earth
name_theory: The name Earth derives from the Old English word 'eorðe' and the German word 'Erde,' which mean ground or soil. Unlike other planets in the Solar System, Earth is not named after a mythological god or goddess.
description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known astronomical object known to harbor and support life. It has a diverse climate, abundant water, and a protective atmosphere that sustains a wide variety of living organisms.
interesting_facts: Earth is the only known planet to support life, with diverse ecosystems ranging from deep oceans to high mountains.
About 71% of Earth's surface is covered by water, primarily in the form of oceans.
Earth's atmosphere is composed of 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, and trace amounts of other gases, including carbon dioxide and water vapor.
Earth has one natural satellite, the Moon, which affects tides and stabilizes the planet's rotation.
Earth's magnetic field protects the planet from harmful solar radiation.
The highest point on Earth is Mount Everest, which stands at 8,848 meters (29,029 feet) above sea level.
The lowest natural point on Earth's surface is the Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench, which lies about 10,994 meters (36,070 feet) below sea level.
Earth's rotation is gradually slowing down at a rate of approximately 1.7 milliseconds per century.
The planet's biodiversity has evolved over billions of years, with millions of species of plants, animals, and microorganisms.
Earth is located in the habitable zone of the Solar System, where conditions are just right for liquid water to exist.
The Earth’s crust is divided into tectonic plates that move and interact, causing earthquakes, volcanic activity, and the formation of mountains.
The planet experiences seasonal changes due to the tilt of its axis relative to its orbital plane.
Earth has a layered structure consisting of the crust, mantle, outer core, and inner core.
The planet’s surface is constantly changing due to processes like erosion, weathering, and plate tectonics.
Earth's average distance from the Sun is about 93 million miles (150 million kilometers), a distance that light travels in about 8 minutes and 20 seconds.
